Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides serves as a welcome corrective, reviving the fun, feather-light frivolity that any film based on a Disneyland ride ought to exhibit.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The stock dismissal "more of the same" has rarely been more accurately applied to a sequel than to The Hangover Part II, which ranks as little more than a faded copy of its predecessor superimposed on a more brightly colored background.
The slapdash animation is matched in kind by the patched-together story.
A cheap-looking, vaguely depressing echo of Robert Rodriguez's well-loved kidpic trilogy, assembled with minimal imagination or effort.
movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Little more than a pleasantly passable Christian sports parable delivered as a sort of Texan golfer's version of The Karate Kid.
Like any mixtape, it offers some truly transcendent moments alongside a smattering of filler, and never quite assembles its pieces into a cohesive whole.
The Big Bang is a borderline unintelligible, scattershot attempt at Lynchian neo-noir that takes intellectual and aesthetic risks it has no reasonable hope of pulling off.
A puerile kiddie-comedy without the anarchic energy, and a schmaltzy romantic comedy without the sweetness.
Though anyone who needs convincing won't touch this one with a 10-foot pole, Justin Bieber: Never Say Never makes a persuasive case for its titular star as a far more talented-than-usual teen idol.

[The film] gives the seminal early '90s hip-hop group as stylish and intimate a treatment as fans could hope for, paying as much attention to the music in question as it does to the characters who made it.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The script is never nearly as clever as the premise ought to allow, and the madcap fun is far too frequently derailed by tonal inconsistencies.
An unfunny, manipulative romance about two unlikable people and their prop of a son, the pic mangles the premise of its source material.
A brotherly love tale substantially weightier than its baseball road-trip premise might indicate.
Equal parts bold experiment (in sustaining a YouTube aesthetic for an entire film), and shallow redux of well-worn teenage sex comedy tropes.
Not without charm and bearing easy appeal to very young viewers.
Jovovich remains the lone light in the increasingly lackluster videogame-based zombie franchise, which barrels through its fourth installment with a threatened fifth on the way.
Director Zack Snyder attempts to shoehorn his heavily art-directed mayhem into a kiddie-pic mold with predictably ill-fitting results.
movie_title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Those bemoaning the lack of quality female roles in modern-day Hollywood will find a key cause celebre in You Again, which manages to squander three generations of formidable actresses.
A genially midrange if overlong romantic comedy.
This meandering, talky film-industry satire never manages to rouse itself from a near-comatose level of self-satisfaction.
Season of the Witch is a fine example of a film that would've been great fun if only its creators had a sense of humor about the wild brew of absurdity they had percolating.
Vivid photography, true-to-life moments and a wonderful lead performance compensate for some first-timer missteps in debutante writer-director Dee Rees' Pariah.
Like Crazy is an exquisite, beautifully acted gem of a film, one that should serve as a prelude to bigger things for stars Felicity Jones and Anton Yelchin, as well as director Drake Doremus.
Picked up by Magnet, "Shotgun" should satisfy midnight movie gore-hounds.
Careless and bedraggled in its storytelling and never aiming its sights beyond the most obvious targets.
The protagonists have become more likable and empowered, motivations have become more cut and dried, and references to underlying political schisms are downplayed.
This ruthlessly unfunny misfire should be quickly relegated to an IMDb trivia question after a brief theatrical bow.
Too silly to be scary, and a bit too dull to be a midnight-movie guilty pleasure.

An idle Netflix user could certainly do far worse when browsing for mindless actioners. But the overall air of shrugging obligation from those both in front of and behind the camera proves contagious.
It has a certain outlandish purity of purpose which Heche and Oh follow through on with demonic intensity, making for a film that's just as hard to embrace as it is to dismiss.

A relentlessly charming romantic comedy that sees director Lone Scherfig ... finally expand the sensibilities she displayed with "Italian for Beginners" and "An Education" into a more commercial direction.

Given such a glut of recent documentary material on the 54-year-old band, the question has to be asked: Does this particular Rolling Stones film really have any pressing need to exist? In the case of "Olé," the answer is: "maybe not, but so what?"
movie_title: The Rolling Stones: Olé Olé Olé! - A Trip Across Latin America (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Hysterical, feverish, incredibly watchable ...
Discount it at your peril: This portrait of the artist as an old woman is a gentle-hearted gem, as profoundly subtle as it is subtly profound.
movie_title: The B-Side: Elsa Dorfman's Portrait Photography (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Demme proves he's still a wily master of the craft, and the director's work here makes this more than just a fans-only proposition.
It doesn't take too long for Jim Sheridan's period romance "The Secret Scripture" to contort itself into a befuddlingly bungled mess. But at the outset, it seems to have everything going for it.
This spiraling story of sex, murder, darts, premillennial dread and authorial anxiety becomes a veritable hash of garish, disassociated tableaux.
A riotously enjoyable, appropriately deafening flashback to one of the last moments in music history when a bunch of knuckleheads with guitars could conquer the world on chutzpah alone.
A weary, half-hearted affair that doesn't even have the courage of its own nihilism.
The story of the Clash is a fascinating one, and spotlighting a kid inspired by, but not a part of, the punk milieu has plenty of potential. But "London Town" just never burns brightly enough.
Rarely do five minutes elapse between some sort of laugh-out-loud absurdity, and the distinction between the film's intentional and unintentional comedy grows hazier as it goes.
The film sketches an effective, if ultimately somewhat schematic, picture of the legal system's countless crevasses and sinkholes into which a blameless person can easily be shoved.
It lives and dies on Lister-Jones and Pally's chemistry, which the film is just as willing to test as to nurture.
"Before the Flood" may not tackle too much new ground, but given the sincerity of its message, its ability to assemble such a watchable and comprehensive account gives it an undeniable urgency.
Ewan McGregor's directorial debut is as flat and strangled as Philip Roth's novel is furious and expansive.
This glorified video game trailer combines eye-popping visuals with an eye-crossing story.
Never strays too far from its source, essentially repeating the same jump scare, over and over again, for most of its muscular 80 minute running time. What's most shocking is how well it still works.
West's grasp of the rhythms and the grace notes of the Western idiom is undeniable, but he never seems to find a film worth telling within it.
Nick Kroll and Jenny Slate nail the nobility of resentment in this winningly featherweight romantic comedy.
An atmospheric thriller with hardly an ounce of excess fat.

As a pure visual spectacle, however, Batman V Superman ably blows the hinges off the multiplex doors, and editor David Brenner does excellent work to comprehensibly streamline the chaos, capably captured by d.p. Larry Fong.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Max Records gives a sharp performance in this endearing first adaptation of Dan Wells' YA series.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Jon Favreau brings a welcome lightness of touch to this visually immersive adventure story.
Struggling to generate much tension, the film opts for sensory battery in the action scenes, rendering gunshots as loud as cannon fire and splashing blood every which way.
The casting of Zoe Saldana is scarcely the only problematic element of Cynthia Mort's misconceived Nina Simone biopic.
This is a debut of undeniable promise, both for its director and its largely unknown cast.
Atrociously written, begrudgingly acted, haphazardly assembled and never more backward than when it thinks it's being progressive ...
Tries its best to visually convey just how revolutionary Pele's arrival on the scene must have felt, but it's continually hamstrung by an uninspiring, ultra-traditionalist narrative.
The problem with "Alice" is its lack of narrative imagination.
The film hangs together surprisingly well, thanks to on-point performances from George Clooney and Julia Roberts, a sprinkle of obtuse humor and Foster's streamlined direction ...
These are deep, complicated issues the film wades into, and it quickly winds up out of its depth.
Lost Angels is a warm, humanistic portrait of Los Angeles' Skid Row.
movie_title: Lost Angels: Skid Row Is My Home (2012)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to fault the movie's earnestness; Hallström's canine cinema pedigree (which includes the superior "Hachi: A Dog's Tale") shows through; and Rachel Portman's score is understandably sentimental without going completely saccharine.
Making a few admirable attempts to complicate what could have been a standard-issue inspirational sports narrative, "Race" is better than it has to be, but not by too much ...

Gorgeously shot, and helmed with a sense of daring and verve that belies Hamilton's greenness to feature filmmaking, this is a debut of obvious promise, although its story never quite rises to the level of its craft.

Funny, warm, and broken-in in all the right ways, "Win It All" marries Swanberg's loping, observational style with a plot that wouldn't have been out of place in an old-school Warner Bros. melodrama, and ends up dealing a surprisingly strong hand.
"Disobedience" may not catapult Lelio beyond the arthouse world, but it's yet another triumph in what's shaping up to be a major career.
The film amounts to essentially a long, intimate brunch conversation with its inimitable subject, and for those with even a passing interest in fashion, that should be plenty.
At times a tad too subtle, "Thelma" is nonetheless an unnervingly effective slow-burn, and those with the patience for Trier's patient accumulation of detail will find it pays off in unexpected ways.

[Close] is a marvel of twisty understatement here, delivering emotions that conceal as much as they reveal, and offering onion-like layers that invite repeat viewings in light of some of the film's later revelations.

Still plenty entertaining and occasionally very funny, "Ninjago" nonetheless displays symptoms of diminishing returns, and Lego might want to shuffle its pieces a bit before building yet another film with this same model.
Expanded from her award-winning short of the same title, Oh Lucy! betrays some rough edges in the transition, but Hirayanagi's idiosyncratic touch marks her as a talent worth tracking.
... it's an entirely watchable if entirely by-the-numbers throwback to the sweet-and-sour Sundance-style indie films of yore.
About as inessential as reboots get, "Flatliners"... otherwise offers no reason for reanimating this long-expired property.
"Humor Me" manages to earn its audience's indulgence, if never its full affection.

"Death Cure" is the most successful entry in the franchise by far. It may be too late to turn the cultural tide on the genre, but it comes as a relief to see at least one series manage to stick the landing.
It is first and foremost an irresistible hangout movie, offering a thoroughly millennial, vérité spin on '80s skater classics like "Thrashin'."

Dull, flavorless, and fundamentally incurious, "The Outsider" is a clueless misfire, the cinematic equivalent of a study-abroad student showing off the kanji forearm tattoo whose meaning he never bothered to learn.
If our divided country can't come together over a movie this wonderfully terrible, what hope do we really have?

Runs through spy movie cliches with such dogged obligation that it often plays like a YouTube compilation of scenes from older, better thrillers, generating little overall tension and only occasionally approaching basic coherence.
"The Last Key" is wildly uneven, confused and confusing, and it appears to leave the "Insidious" saga written into a corner yet again.
What it can't do ... is generate even the slightest bit of interest in what happens to any of its characters.

Impressively shot and suffused with a righteous feminist fire, the film is undercut by a confused and clunky script and a fundamental lack of thematic focus, turning an extraordinary story into didactic and disjointed melodrama.
Green looks for small but meaningful ways to complicate and deepen the well-trod story he's telling, and by the end, those complications help the film earn its uplift.

So much uncut hardboiled posturing proves exhausting over a nearly two-hour runtime, and with zero emotional stakes and a plot that is both difficult and seemingly pointless to follow, there's a fundamental emptiness behind all the flash.
[This] simply-structured film is harrowingly effective in its streamlined, low-frills way: sensitive without ever being sanctimonious, brutally frank without ever lapsing into exploitation.
Nothing here, from the premise to the plotting to the basic tone, is particularly novel, but the entire affair has a distinctive personality.

While it certainly has its moments, it remains frustratingly one-note, too cool to really commit to the screwball farce the premise is crying out for, and too enamored with picking off easy targets to draw real blood.
At its best, "Tragedy Girls" plays like a sweet story of a believable high school friendship between two girls who just happen to be sociopaths.

"M.F.A.'s" themes call for a careful, consistent tone that it is rarely able to maintain, and an increasingly ridiculous third act squanders much of the empathy and engagement that Leite works so hard to build in the early going.
Its unabashedly folky, less-is-more approach proves quietly moving.
Once a darkly comic romp centered around outing a pedophile teacher, this adaptation has been shorn of its sharpest edges, leaving a largely unfocused, conventional teen dramedy in its place.

A peek under the hood reveals a rather shopworn story that doesn't completely sell its more melodramatic narrative strands, but [also] to a trio of finely calibrated performances, an authentic sense of place and one gorgeously designed red '36 Chevy.
The franchise has lost a bit of its luster with every successive installment, but never has a "Pirates" film felt this inessential, this depressingly pro forma.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Patty Jenkins' Wonder Woman provides a welcome respite from DC's house style of grim darkness with star Gal Gadot proving an inspired choice for this avatar of truth, justice and the Amazonian way.
"Wish Upon" is a pretty bad movie. But its badness is of such a distinct and kooky character that it can't help but exert an inadvertent charm.
An unusual beauty pageant offers an emotionally vivid look at the lives of female veterans.
King fans will surely appreciate the clear effort and affection that went into this adaptation, even as it struggles to become more than the sum of its parts.
Pummeling, overlong, and at times a bit too proud of its own provocations, "Bodied" is nonetheless a feverishly entertaining spectacle ...
Taking an ode to the power of musical rebellion and running it through the mill of committee-thinking winds up being no rock and roll fun.
The latest, and quite possibly worst, tissue-thin weepie to issue forth from the Nicholas Sparks page-to-screen assembly line ...
Often it feels like sitting through an endless series of half-remembered shaggy dog stories screamed from across the bar by someone who's had two glasses too many.
If director Dexter Fletcher's loose adaptation of Edwards' story often seems content to mimic "Cool Runnings" beat for beat, at least it picks a bar it can safely clear.

Director Charles Hood's sophomore feature could have gone south in any number of ways. Fortunately, the execution here is impressively adroit, with a clever script enlivened by two charmingly compatible lead performances from Rosa Salazar and Adam Pally.
The cheekiest, funniest, and most purely entertaining entry in the Disneynature series.
Essentially just a slightly gussied-up version of the types of "making of" featurettes that sometimes accompany deluxe album packages.
movie_title: Mary J. Blige: The London Sessions (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Portia Doubleday stars in a frothy teen comedy as unobjectionable as it is unmemorable.

Keaton and Freeman's chemistry goes a long way toward selling this trifle, and whatever it may lack in drama, it is refreshing to see a happy golden-years marriage depicted with such affection onscreen.
Reese Witherspoon and Sofia Vergara can't save this lazy, unfunny action-comedy.
Hansen-Love, who co-wrote the script along with her former-DJ brother Sven, zeroes in on the signature experiences of '90s club life with expert precision.
A scintillating lead performance, a good deal of heart and a fragrant sense of place just about compensate for some slack storytelling and a forcibly elegiac tone ...
California crumbles spectacularly in an action movie that quickly degenerates from blissfully stupid to fatally stupid.
At no point does anyone involved with the film ever take this too seriously, and as long as one takes it in the same spirit, it's perfectly enjoyable.
Director Ben Chace's drama offers a sensual, brainy immersion in scenes of Cuban life past and present.

Though Stray Dog is slowly paced and at times a bit repetitive, Granik and her crew rarely risk losing their audience's attention, and they uncover a wealth of images that are alternately striking, symbolic and singular.
Les Blank's long-lost Leon Russell documentary is a beguiling snapshot of a lost era.
movie_title: A Poem Is A Naked Person (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Often riotously funny.
[A] professionally executed yet bloodless film ... an act of homage that hews reverently to its source material while missing the essential spirit and vitality that once powered it.

This earnest, slight romance doesn't generate enough sparks to overcome the anxiety of its obvious influence. But as a simple valentine to Hong Kong's expat nightlife, the film makes for charming, breezy viewing.
At times there's a genuine sense of daring to the film's freewheeling anarchy, its refusal to stick to a central theme or impart any sort of lesson.
movie_title: The SpongeBob Movie: Sponge Out of Water (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film's initial formulaic competence gives way to outright preposterousness rather quickly, hinging on idiot-plot character motivations, "It was only a cat!" jump scares and computer files that may as well be labeled "Evil Schemes, 2012-2014."
The film never manages to transcend its actors-workshop aura and develop into something deeper.

Its surfeit of half-baked film-student flourishes and needless cameos occasionally give it an amateur-hour feel. But Franco nonetheless shows improvement over 2013's "As I Lay Dying," and well, it's hard to fault him for trying.
Gugu Mbatha-Raw gives a fierce lead turn in Gina Prince-Bythewood's messy but undeniably entertaining music-biz romance.
A wonderfully innervating cure for the common musical biopic ...
A slow-motion zeppelin crash that starts as a dull-edged fable, and then spirals further and further out of control without ever growing more exciting or interesting.

Tucker Green certainly isn't shy about testing her audience's patience, and while she can sometimes get a bit too enamored with her own moody, elliptical atmospherics, there's clearly a unique imagination at work here ...
The best that can be said of this documentary is that it makes enough gestures toward fair and balanced treatment to obscure much of the bad faith lying beneath.
Too formally well crafted to be dismissed, but too straightforward and uncurious to be particularly exciting or insightful ...
Jeremy Renner gives his best performance since 'The Hurt Locker' in this assiduous, engrossing drama about the late investigative reporter Gary Webb.
Man From Reno is hardly the equal of its inspirations, but it nonetheless makes for a pleasantly mellow, well-structured concoction.
With a Sharknado-inspired visual style and a deeply weary lead performance from Nicolas Cage, Left Behind is cheap-looking, overwrought kitsch of the most unintentionally hilarious order.
This well-intentioned weepie never quite rises far enough above its movie-of-the week architecture to hit all its intended emotional pressure points.
Sporadically funny and mostly tedious, this 18-years-too-late sequel nonetheless exhibits a puerile purity of purpose.
A searing, horrifying, at times starkly beautiful documentary ode to the netherworlds surrounding the U.S.-Mexico barrier.
movie_title: Purgatorio: A Journey Into the Heart of the Border (2014)

movie_review_blurb: "The Wind Cries Mary," "Fire" and "Manic Depression" were all composed during the time period covered by the film, yet never does Hendrix convincingly appear to be an artist in bloom.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Thorpe's documentary can sometimes seem a bit intimidated by the various cans of worms it pries open, but it's nonetheless a breezy, funny, often quite clever film more concerned with minor epiphanies than big answers.
Unbalanced, unwieldy, and at times nearly unintelligible, Aloha is unquestionably Cameron Crowe's worst film.
Farley's story seems to be a sadder and more complicated one than the filmmakers appear fully comfortable exploring.

Goes through all the motions of an old-school wartime spy pic with plenty of technical competence but zero panache, the filmic equivalent of a bar band working through one last Skynyrd cover just before last call.
Hysterical, insightful and genuinely empathetic ...
Bill Murray heads to Afghanistan in director Barry Levinson's dreadfully misguided farce.
One would have to trawl through the deepest recesses of Romanian art cinema to find a film with as many static, silent shots of empty rooms and unfurnished hallways.
Brad Coley's slow-paced thriller has a decent cast, but can't draw the viewer into its convoluted, overstuffed mystery.
There's an unmistakable, scathing sense of outrage behind the whole endeavor, and it's impossible not to admire McKay's reckless willingness ...

If it's remembered for nothing else, and it almost certainly won't be, Uli Edel's "Pay the Ghost" can at least make a claim to being the first film to feature a haunted razor scooter in a horror setpiece.
Not only lives up to the best of its predecessors, but also respectfully forges its own path.

Thanks to director Rock Baijnauth's playful, nonjudgmental approach to these obsessive characters, the whole enterprise comes across as endearingly -- and perhaps even admirably -- ridiculous, rather than laughably so.
This skewed take on Mary Shelley's classic never shows enough sparks of life to justify reanimating its nearly 200-year-old source.
A mostly harmless yet plenty rough assemblage of musical numbers and rote chases that barely add up to a movie ...
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Road Chip (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Diablo" boasts the skeleton of an interesting allegorical oater ... but Carlos de los Rios' screenplay never manages to provide flesh or a beating heart, leaving the whole endeavor feeling more like a rough draft.
Kim A. Snyder's Sandy Hook documentary is an elegant, devastating portrait of a town in mourning.

The whole cast and crew all put in a solid shift at the office making the movie, producing a perfectly entertaining, sometimes quite well-crafted disaster drama that nonetheless retreats from the memory almost as soon as the credits roll.
This initially droll, then increasingly nightmarish tale has atmosphere to spare along with some good jolts.
Hysterical, insightful and genuinely empathetic ...
Peter Landesman's drama pulls no punches in its critique of the NFL, but a cliched, confused script lets the film down.
A film that generally succeeds in spite of its formulaic underpinnings and loose ends.
Unfortunately, it fails to find much humor in them, and its potent sense of place and underlying ideas never compensate for the tiresome millennial musings that constitute most of its runtime.
Stripping all whimsy and wonder from the Peter Pan story, Joe Wright's prequel is a busy, bungled bust.
This is a shaggy, easily distractible film that consistently defies expectations to both charming and baffling effect.
Too often plays like an earnest yet unsatisfying adaptation of a cult graphic novel, with most of the charm lost in translation.
Anyone who found the original a cut above the average horror pic will likely leave the theater disappointed, if not downright insulted.
An almost bizarrely limp, emotionless, blank greeting card of a movie.
movie_title: An Eye for Beauty (Le règne de la beauté) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most enjoyable bad movies of the year.
Awkward and unsatisfying.
Despite committed performances from Tom Hiddleston and Elizabeth Olsen, Marc Abraham's Hank Williams biopic is a dull, unfocused slog.
Nicholas Hoult embodies the psychosis of the 1990s British music industry in this initially sharp, increasingly tiresome and violent satire.
Dellal's likably chaotic direction and a bevy of solid performances make sure the film's beating heart outweighs most of its contrivances.
Ethan Hawke gives one of the best performances of his career in Robert Budreau's Chet Baker non-biopic.
Curran's tasteful, challenging yet ultimately inscrutable debut feature never quite lives up to the caliber of her fine cast.
The tone never quite gels, leaving the film an eye-catching but weightless mishmash of hit-and-miss one-liners and bloody yet non-visceral firefights.
What could have been a broad yet sweetly believable comic meditation on cross-cultural middle-aged romance [is dragged] down with flatly staged, sometimes downright infantile low-brow antics.
The latest 'Maze Runner' movie succeeds well enough as derivative survival-horror-action thrillers go, but makes for an unsatisfying, confusing sequel.

The princess deserved no lesser tribute from her magnificent sons. They are her greatest legacy. Yet one still wonders if it was wise for then to disburden their long-suppressed grief and love in this manner.
movie_title: Diana, Our Mother: Her Life and Legacy (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Under the direction of Michael Winterbottom and the exquisite cinematography of James Clarke, a sense of place is not something The Trip lacks. It is just as impressive, however, that this mixture of inspired improvisation and deliberate writing.
While cryptic in story and minimalist in form, this brave new offering from Studio Ghibli quietly dazzles.
movie_title: The Tale of the Princess Kaguya (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Go and see My Love, Don't Cross that River: if, by its ending, it hasn't moved you to your core, you have an invulnerable heart.
movie_title: My Love, Don't Cross That River (2016)

movie_review_blurb: "...reaches for great heights and doesn't always get there."
A dated, tired and underwritten fantasy; cosplay history with an onslaught of battle scenes.
A mesmeric nightmare of violence and exploitation in the underbelly of a modern Indian city.
Rom-com fanatics and Austen aficionados may find gems in Austenland, but others will see this as a film with little sense or sensibility.
The Boy and the Beast is a beautifully warm film that rides on a wave of emotion and fantasy.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Assassin's Creed is the best video game adaptation ever made which, unfortunately, is not hard to be.
Lost in France is a bittersweet and often hilarious tale of friendship, sheer luck and the absolute power music can have. Its message is one of get up and go.

Buddy cop comedies are rarely good and CHiPs is unfortunately no exception... Director, writer, and star Dax Shepard was clearly never told that some things are better left in the past where they rightfully belong.

Free Fire has set a high standard for action cinema in 2017 and beyond. While highly stylised action is nowhere near dead Wheatley makes a convincing argument for bringing Western action back to its roots.
he Edge of Seventeen is a good coming-of-age film but that's all it is.
Atomic Blonde is a film that, despite its flaws, should not be missed.
Wind River is one of the best films of 2017.
It's an agonising bore to anyone over the age of seven but is having an hour and a half of peace and quiet really worth both the financial and temporal cost? I highly doubt it.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Borg vs McEnroe succeeds in immortalising two titans of the game of tennis all the while capturing exactly what makes the game so interesting.
Though not of the same calibre as their most paradigmatic work Early Man will undoubtedly be recognised as an instant classic.
Were it not for the relatively exciting heist and the thrilling gun battle that finishes it, Den of Thieves would be a very bad film. Instead, it flounders just below the average mark.
47 Metres Down attempts and mostly succeeds to scare and chill.
Few films have so vividly re-created the sensation of having known another human being for one's entire life, while simultaneously evoking the suspicion that all along one has loved a stranger.
Rivaling China's finest documentarians, first-time director Lixin Fan begins his Last Train Home with a handful of unshakable images.
Things start to go awry when we realize that the film's emotional sensitivity doesn't go much deeper than its moody surfaces.

Designed as one big, sloppy thesp-a-thon, the film adaptation of August: Osage County interprets one of the past decade's most overly hyped dramas with the conviction usually lavished on top-drawer Eugene O'Neill.
Apart from its handcrafted visuals, which are as lovely and painstakingly precise as anything in the Ghibli canon, the film feels sapped of conflict and energy
Though the film offers nothing new for the eyes, its wordiness ultimately acts as a complement rather than a drawback to Almodóvar's masterful storytelling.
In his determination to position the film as a universal love story, Lou sacrifices the political engagement and specificity that makes the work of queer auteurs ( ... ) so valuable
Only a country where marriage equality is a foregone conclusion could produce a film about gay politics bled of all rage and resentment.

Don Cheadle's flimsily conceived Miles Davis passion project...never lingers in the mind long enough to do the music much damage...The film is undone not by its interpretation of Davis's legacy but by its caper plot.
Yet the voice resonating behind these familiar motifs is one of such dazzling originality, it's hard to emerge from this waking dream of a film without feeling the shock of the new.
The Ornithologist, is no less attuned to the shock and awe of corporeal experience, but here the fixation is couched in an almost overpowering serenity.
Daughter of the Nile represents something special: the kind of modestly crafted masterpiece a director makes just before he comes into recognition of his own stature.
movie_title: Daughter of the Nile (Ni luo he nu er) (1987)

movie_review_blurb: It's disappointing to watch the film fall into Behind the Music conventionality, employing a perfunctory alternation of talking heads and archival material despite the fact that so much once-rare footage can now be seen on YouTube.

There are some nail-biting in-car point of view shots as the drivers career around circuits at high speed. We're used to seeing similar footage on our TV screens every race day but on the big screen you get a real feeling of the speed these guys reach.
What a thrill-packed, rip-roaring adventure it is.
As well as being dramatically and visually engaging, the film conjures a living ecosystem that pulses, grips and ultimately enchants.
Hard as nail crime saga with a blistering central performance.
Warm, subtle and gentle, The Descendants demonstrates what can happen when indie talent is nurtured to mainstream success.
The violence is effectively tailored around Carano's undeniable skills...
The argot, drugs and council-estate setting may put some audiences off, but they would be missing a socially conscious, energetic horror comedy that's scary and very funny.

It's a boldly modernist approach designed to irritate purists, and although it's pleasingly tactile, it's perhaps too avant garde; its fractured narrative and glimpses of lens flare constantly break the spell of the period fiction.
The claustrophobic, VDU-illuminated isolationism of the financial services industry is cleverly implied, as the central disaster is humanised by individual ones...
Without the award-worthy Streep, it's just high-quality historical karaoke.
Fans of E4's cult sixth-form sitcom The Inbetweeners are laser-targeted by this feature-length excursion.
Many will find it ponderous and indulgent, but too often modern cinema is efficient and focus-grouped. The work of Terrence Malick becomes ever more vital as an antidote.
Despite amusing moments and a sprinkling of catnip for film buffs, Hitchcock is disappointingly inconsequential.

movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An actors' showcase and a hefty serving of director Michael Haneke's self indulgence

A giant screen to tell an intimate yet soaring story

Not as humorous as I'd like, mind you, and you have to totally surrender to the silliness to make this work.
movie_title: La Personne aux Deux Personnes (The Person Who Is Two Persons) (Me Two) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The irony of the Sunshine named small enterprise specialising in cleaning up post-death mess suggests the filmmakers may be aiming for a tone of dark comic entertainment, but the film does not play out that way.

This superbly constructed and executed film gets everything right, to the smallest detail, as it draws us into the imagined scenario.

A powerful yet nuanced work

Thoroughly engaging

The jungle scenes are marvellous, the 'savages' are beautiful and exotic, and the mantra that a man's 'reach should be greater than his grasp' clearly articulated.
Although the material is slight, the humanity and its universality make it cinematic, if not entirely satisfying.
A wrenching portrait.

The humour is British - low key but often barbed - and the filmmakers manage to control the tone of the film through the many elements of the human experience from love and art to death and broken relationships.
The most profound accomplishment of this haunting film is Chadha's ability to manage the multi-protagonist elements and the multi-layered story, forging a cohesive and satisfying epic.
A sensational fusion of cinema, theatre and music, Amadeus from the National Theatre in HD is one of the most satisfying, rewarding and engaging cinematic events of my year.
it fails the authenticity test, and gives rise to the sad thought that it's the result of a creative draught.
Another jolly roger of a comedic adventure in the Caribbean, Pirates 5 (for shorthand) is as robust as it is helter skelter.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Driven by wonderful performances from all, notably Brian Cox as Churchill and Miranda Richardson as Clemmie ... not forgetting a superb cameo by James Purefoy at King George VI.
Edited into a cohesive work, the film provides more than a glimpse, less than a complete insight, but it is a fascinating exploration for fans and anyone else interested in the human condition.
It's a bitter sweet story of a shooting star, its trajectory similar to any one of a handful of rock stars and the like, but given added depth, texture and resonance by history and circumstance.
Theatre director William Oldroyd distinguishes himself with this feature debut, demonstrating a strong cinematic instinct, letting images work; they speak volumes.

It's jaw dropping at times, the level of obsession exhibited by these chicken people, and illuminating to realise that there is a whole big world - a very big world - full of show chickens and other poultry.

Exhibiting the same subtle yet sharp stabs of humour that distinguished her Lost in Translation (2003), Sofia Coppola has fashioned a film that is even more beautiful than her The Virgin Suicides (1999).

Fun for Francophiles, this is the armchair equivalent of touring France by car, allowing us to sit still while the travel unfolds on the screen, along with taste-bud tingling cuisine, wonderful wine and a bit of low level romantic sparkle.

For all its taut direction and editing, its thunderous sound and its historic origins, the film doesn't quite move us as deeply and as often as we expect. Perhaps Nolan is trying too hard to construct the mood with the tools at his command.

Truth to Power? Lies to people, would be a more accurate title for this blurt of propaganda which ends with calls for us in the audience to be #beinconvenient and to help push Al Gore's agenda for renewable energy and wipe coal off the face of the earth.
movie_title: An Inconvenient Sequel: Truth To Power (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Plagiarising their real life experiences on the road to romance, Kumail Nanjiani and Emily V. Gordon have written a screenplay that oozes with the black comedy of life, which is of course the good oil of strong comedy.

Agent Lorraine Broughton (Charlize Theron) distinguishes herself in many ways among the genre's spies, from her vodka fetish to her bold fashion sense to her savage fighting skills and not least, to her sensual beauty.
The themes of this story include cultures, family, retribution and the essentials of survival in the wilderness, even if that is within a helicopter ride of urban life.
Some of the chatter is borderline silly, but Liman holds it all together with astute filmcraft - and Taylor-Johnson's gritty performance.
Embrace is an uplifting and engaging film with plenty of guts, setting out the social parameters that constrain women of almost all ages by impossible, self imposed criteria. Good on her

The film belongs to Mark Ruffalo in many ways, the central figure whose addiction, failure and redemption takes us in and out of laughter, tears and introspection. Gwyneth Paltrow is fresh and fabulous as Phoebe

This odd couple is a hook for black comedy. They do bad things. Bad things happen to them. Life poops in their soup. Just like any of us, really, and that's why we love to laugh at them, with them, about them and despite them
This is one hulluva documentary, and not because of Anthony Weiner's sexting about his weiner
The first half of the film, all taking place inside Room, filled with action and suspense, is intense, engaging and intriguing, with the best, most inventive writing. It isn't sustained, though
Aaron Sorkin's screenplay and Danny Boyle's direction give us a Steve Jobs profile that does not idolise or flatter him. As a result, the film gains respect and we gain insight
Superficially simple, Anomalisa is actually a thoroughly complex web of human experience, recognisably real, even though the characters are 30 cm tall stop motion puppets
Brooklyn deals with universal themes, but through the most intimate prism of a young woman who is starting to shape her life, uncertainly, walking into the future without a handrail

It may not be original, but what the film lacks in freshness it makes up in cinematic bravura, from 'breaking the fourth wall' (talking to the audience) to self referential nonsense amidst violent mayhem
Oscar Wilde is the undoubted and unseen star of this play - always was and will be. His wit, encased in sublime and wicked use of English, is not only sharp, it is pointedly observed and satirical
movie_title: The Importance Of Being Earnest Live (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's full of both gravitas and titillation, as perhaps any true story is; there is the destruction of lives and careers on one hand, and the spectacle of the players on the other - with Hollywood stars of the 40s and 50s as more or less support players
I am a sucker for cause films that champion right against might, but even allowing for that bias, I can recommend Concussion as engaging cinematic grit
As a piece of cinema, Spotlight (the name of the investigative team at the Boston Globe) is exceptional

Faithful to the scriptures (as it were) Risen is a sort of redemption story inasmuch as Roman Tribune Clavius (Joseph Fiennes) finally comes to believe in the resurrection - and in the personage of Yeshua (Clifton Curtis) as the Messiah

The wry tone, the dry wit and the sometimes not so dry moment (eg synchronised water dancing led by the irritable (and pregnant) DeeAnna Moran (Scarlett Johansson), serve as flavouring to this Coen brothers movie meal
If you think that having seen your share of Holocaust movies you have seen them all, you are in for a surprise
The challenge for Michael Bay was to make a compelling drama from a story whose ending is neither Hollywood-happy nor unknown. It is to his credit that he meets the challenge
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The combination of aerial photography with archival material provides plenty of texture not just eye candy, and the simplicity of the film allows the giant IMAX images to rule

With its patchwork story, sewn together from disparate plotlines (perhaps collated from discarded script ideas), 10 Cloverfield Lane can be trying on our patience when it should be tightening the tension screws.
Visually and viscerally effective, intelligent and haunting

Full of excruciating truths about impossible choices in war, Guy Hibbert's screenplay is a searing, gripping and heart wrenching work that is superbly transposed from page to screen by a fabulous cast in the hands of a director who knows his craft
The beauty of the women's bodies and the splendor of the location are meant to seduce us, and that is ironic since that seduction is as shallow as the characters

Getting a Pulitzer Prize for restaurant criticism must attract our attention, and Jonathan Gold's enthusiasm coupled with his eye (and palate) for places off the beaten food critics track kinda explain the prize
Full of loud misery and fiery battle, the film is a derivative of its genre and other filmic elements
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: I surprised myself how easily the film seduced me into its world, despite the setting being at odds with the cast and their voices
It's a riveting film, depressing in its critique of a system that was built on greed and fraud - and rebuilt after the crash with taxpayers' money, only to continue its brazen practices today
Well crafted entertainment, delivering on its promise as a romantic comedy, with some serious ballast. The tone is just right
A remarkably well crafted and engaging film from the fine screenplay, superbly cast and beautifully executed
The sheer verve of the filmmakers earned them the Jury Prize at Cannes, where unique and risky filmmaking is rewarded ahead of commercially satisfying fare
Moorhouse has a clear vision for the material and a great team to help her achieve it
The glance backwards by the writers signals a kind of watershed in the development of the new Bond since Daniel Craig slipped his Baretta into 007's shoulder holster

Audiences will no doubt notice the powerful and important role played by the score, from Australian screen composers Antony Partos and Matteo Zingales; important and remarkably effective
'Never assume anything about anyone' has been my mantra for many years so it is no surprise when characters in a film demonstrate the veracity of that sentiment
It's an event, not just a movie, as Tarantino intended, something to savour, not to rush

It's a film of arresting images, often surreal and fantastical, a visceral work that is void of physical violence yet violent in other ways, absolutely committed to its creative chaos
Well, if it's propaganda, it's very well done, convincingly making the case for ethanol and methanol as well as biofuel in general - at least in the US market

A seamless blend of buddy movie, gambling movie and road movie, Mississippi Grind delivers two terrific central performances from Ben Mendelsohn as Gerry and Ryan Reynolds as Curtis, two losers - with optimism
Well, was it worth the wait and the anticipation? In my book, yes
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Good comedy rests on genuine dramatic foundations, a rule this film surely affirms
Peggy Guggenheim became an art addict, yes, but she was also a bit of a sex addict, according to those who knew her, many of them speaking kindly but frankly about her dual addiction

Masterful filmmaker Ron Howard conducts his team in a symphonic, even operatic telling of a terrifying sea drama that is filled with so many aspects of human experience that we can't count them
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film is more than another mea culpa: it's a well crafted piece of cinema with outstanding performances, evocative score and design and powerful cinematography

Documentary is a fascinating genre: it can lead filmmakers to unexpected places and smartly opportunistic filmmakers (in the best sense), will take advantage of such opportunities. This is such a case. This is such a film

Fairy tale stuff, yes, but with several redeeming features as well as some darned flaws.
It's a decent story, but the film suffers from the muddling effect of ghost story mixed with thriller.

If you feel a sigh of nostalgia for the era and what you were doing or being at the time, maybe you would get a bigger hit from the film than I.
It's an effective, engaging film, avoiding the expected resolutions for a more authentic result, while engaging us in the issues of how we live together
Made with passion and compassion, Septembers of Shiraz is a marvelously crafted film that leaves a lasting impression
The searing insights are presented with minimal flourish and with riveting storytelling.
Inspired? Absurd? Silly? Genius? Surreal? Fake? Well, in short, unique
It's an entertaining popcorn movie sure to satisfy its target market of younger audiences, done with all the polish that Hollywood money can buy

movie_title: The Measure of a Man (La loi du marché) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Although this adaptation has a few gaps and the genre is more thriller than spy movie, it is a well produced and made movie sausage - no disrespect intended

A surprisingly intimate, revealing and engaging documentary

The many awards and accolades (including an Oscar nomination as Best Foreign Language Film) together with positive reviews quoted on the marketing materials for this film lifted my expectations - perhaps too high
movie_title: Embrace Of The Serpent (El Abrazo De La Serpiente) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What I find noteworthy about this film is that you don't fully realise its power until the ending. It subtly unfolds
movie_title: The Second Mother (Que Horas Ela Volta?) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Technically flawless, The BFG is a fantasy, but Roald Dahl didn't make a name for himself by being insipid

It's an appealing premise to have an atheist dad try to come to terms with a son wishing to be a Catholic priest...The decision to play it for laughs is a disappointment for those who like their humour dry and their conflicts real

The result is a meandering film of disjointed experiences, albeit interesting and beautifully filmed
Deceptively seductive in its veracity and subtlety, Rams engages us, intrigues us and finally moves us beyond our expectations

The temptation to overdo the shtick is resisted, making the film an edgy affair

Fascinating and tense - almost thriller like, the film offers more food for thought than you may anticipate
A wonderful, vibrant, inventive and visually astonishing film, this Alice does justice to the Lewis Carroll creation and justifies harvesting that beloved old world

In this froth of a film, everything is a bit larger than life, but it's done with a nice sense of abandon and it's grounded by the performances

An intimate film, not suitable for the harsh and bloated ambiance of the multiplex, and while it is modest, it is also sincere

Every 8 - 10 year old, and adults with 8 - 10 year old funny bones, will guffaw and giggle at the dim wits with big hearts whose originators are part of showbiz royalty. The iconic threesome are resurrected in look and sound-alikes

movie_title: Once Upon a Time in Anatolia (2012)

Recommended for anyone interested in how a lone woman can alter history with a strict code of anti- violence - as did moral giants such as Mahatma Gandhi, Dr Martin Luther King and Nelson Mandela among others. It's inspirational and reassuring

...doesn't have the emotional involvement of the best of sci-fi action films, but it's a thrashing good big dipper ride and the 3D actually works

Honest and authentic, the filmmaker takes his subject seriously and gives us a complex and thought provoking film

Beautifully performed by all the actors, not least the youngsters

Oh dear. Guy Ritchie has been bankrolled to pillage Arthur Conan Doyle's famous detective once more, despite the raspberries from critics two years ago, and is as determined to present Sherlock Holmes and Dr Watson as figments of his own imagination.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: All the English charm has been sucked out of the story and replaced by less appealing replica in which the joys are few and far between
Heartfelt and sometimes heartbreaking story about love, death, duty and responsibility
Satisfyingly complex and captivating, the film holds our attention for the entire 158 minutes of running time
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Never mind that the tone wavers and the pace is mostly plodding, the film champions all the right things and the beautifully crafted images (in 3D glory) leave a lasting impression

The deliberate pace, the underplayed naturalism of the settings, the closely observed details and the silken threads of relationships all combine to turn the spy thriller into character driven drama
A sardonic story in which we get to see inside all the characters with extraordinary clarity. This is what makes Young Adult special - and so satisfying
War Horse is a soppy, schmaltzy film about the great love between a teenage boy and a young horse, but it's quality schmaltz

Pleasant enough but lacking the grounding (even with Caine in tow) that would give the film some badly needed edge, the entire adventure is based on perfunctory elements that seem shallow and artificial. But then this is an escapist movie

Inspired by a wonderfully inspiring true story, Dolphin Tale has all the right ingredients for a family movie with adorable dolphins ..and the plucky youngster who plays a major role in the feel-good plot

Oddly, for all its deep emotional touchstones and the profoundly sad plot, the film doesn't ignite the fires of our emotions
Based on real events, The First Grader is a unique blend of uplifting self determination and harrowing conflict

The result ... is a missed opportunity to explore the darkest corners of the human condition: the mother of evil
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Olivia Newton John is an absolute hoot as mother in law Barbara in this madcap romantic comedy that brings together English and Australian humour in earthy earnest.
Engrossing, immensely relevant and completely timely, The Ides of March is a triumph for all concerned
As Winston Churchill might have said, never have so many done so little for so many with such dreary results

Arthur Christmas is a deceptively bland title for one of the best films of the year - no matter what your age or where you are on the Santameter. It is a hero's journey, but it is the funniest film ever made about the hugely popular subject of Santa

The movie is rated MA15+ suggesting it's suitable only for those over 15, but the maturity level required is much less

.. engaging and entertaining, at times deadly serious in its own way, with lots to say . . . a satisfying and often funny telling of a great true story
Explores serious themes - some quite dark - with a lightness of touch, providing well observed and genuine humour, sometimes through pain
movie_title: Vincent will Meer (Vincent Wants to Sea) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An astonishing performance by young Thomas Doret as Cyril delivers the core of this well crafted, subtle yet powerful screenplay, which has won several accolades ... challenging yet accessible, sharply observed and emotionally authentic

The cinematic visualisation of the upper class of Pinem - is painted with a surrealist brush that Salvador Dali might have dropped (but).. falls short of expectations, registering a low emotional score despite all that is at stake

movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

The question in this movie's title gets a lot of use. A version of it could also apply to pretty much everyone involved, especially Cranston.
Nothing in the storyline, direction or character types is remotely fresh.
Call it a life story, only funkified.
Its own fascinating beast, bolstered by an inventive, reality-blurring script and a moving performance by Ethan Hawke.

movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Forsaken plays like someone's hazy, half-remembered idea of a Western, from back when men were men, women were dead and "facing the consequences of violence" just meant leaving town on horseback for a while.

The film has good intentions, straining to allow both the howls of creativity and rational pleas for treatment to ring out. But its insight on either end is unremarkable, and its use of visual metaphors is especially tacky.

If it's possible to be pastoral and quaint in a brazen, unapologetic way, Mewshaw and Van Til have managed it: Their film is occasionally lovely, occasionally cloying, and always... what's that word? "Romantic."
It soon becomes apparent that these spunky teens, no matter how much they flirt with each other while brandishing firearms, are only running themselves in circles.
Houston, we have landed in an overtly silly, mod-and-LSD rendition of '69 London that seems on loan from the Austin Powers sets.
The film shifts from Daniel's to Tommie's point of view in a remarkably subtle fashion, altering the makeup of the story and the ways we're forced to wrestle with it.
Think of it as a chance for two people who have been at the top of their game for more than a decade to celebrate their good fortune with a bit of a victory lap. And then another lap.

The humor is very hit-and-miss, both because it's wielding a rather blunt satirical weapon and because the sheer number of people Don fools becomes hard to swallow. But when Don Verdean's barbs land, they work ...
You need a particular alchemy of mood and character to make so much nothing feel so urgent, an alchemy missing from Every Thing.
The characters may look cartoony-and cloyingly cute-but they're wandering through what could be Thomas Hill paintings in panoramic widescreen.
Detail-packed but never dull, with dialogue that absolutely sings and characters we want to stay with forever, it's the kind of work that begs revisiting, like a favorite collection of short stories.
With a lot of help from Bell and Pegg, the movie cheerfully suggests it's possible to stage a lighthearted romance without dropping off your brain beforehand.
The Schulz descendants who oversaw this new Peanuts avoid the obvious traps to ensure a charming, harmless trip down memory lane.
Burnt can't top off its plate with engaging characters or an exciting story. This confection fades almost immediately after it's over, leaving only a slight tingle on the tongue.
Some action heroes take themselves too seriously, or think they're making popcorn fun when they're really filleting us with endless rounds of ammunition. Not Diesel ...
The film goes on, in unsettling fashion, past the point when news media usually stop caring about nightmares like this. And Larson goes on with it, showing us that she never really leaves her Room.
The gender commentary is still on point, and The Final Girls successfully disembowels its target trope. But it works better as film criticism than it does as a film.
A diverting romp that will get the job done for the author's "nerdfighter" fans.
Though darker in tone, and more suitable for older kids, Disney's new take retains the undeniably fun spirit of the earlier film.

There would be use for a properly dark Frozen retelling, more in line with the original tale, where the afflicted actually uses her power for malfeasance. But Freya is a snow day late and a dollar short.
This Hunger Game is one too many, a 2010-era cash grab in its purest form, more akin to a stern-faced curtain call than a fleshed-out story with a beginning, middle, and end.
Being Charlie follows the expected sine-wave trajectory for a movie about addiction recovery, getting worse before things get better. But it does its business with a refreshing, naked honesty.
"How far will they go with this?" we wonder, and cringe every time we get our answer.
Fences is moviemaking as public service, like PBS's Masterpiece Theater: an accessible adaptation of a necessary literary work that few will ever have the opportunity to see onstage.

Johnston and Marks are strong enough in their roles, crafting characters who express uncertainty and fear in vividly different ways, to make you believe their polarizing personalities truly draw confidence and meaning from each other.
The Eyes of My Mother is the rare [horror] entry to give depth to its destructive force, to force those new eyes onto us and make us truly believe the terror of what we see.
Lonergan's film reveals itself as a wellspring of urgently needed compassion and grace.
Arrival, like the Spielberg classic it aspires to, brings the beyond to us. In doing so, it asks a challenging, prescient question: Are we ready to teach, and ready to learn?
The Stooges may be the biggest secret success story in music. Gimme Danger preserves their legacy better than any fan might have dared hope ...
The kind of PG-13 studio comedy where a lot of people trip while swinging their elbows wide so they can knock down furniture as they fall.

The film achieves what the best Disney animated features do: a sense of place that is refined and specific.

Not only does the film effortlessly mock the sense of wonder and the emotional roller-coasters we've all felt watching Pixar's big-eyed sentient objects, but, in its own messed-up way, it provokes some new feelings, too: shock and awe ...
Last Days in the Desert is the most intelligent, engaging film about Jesus since The Last Temptation of Christ.

What's remarkable about the film is that it sets up what could have been a bunch of pat, dumb culture-clash jokes about a black New York kid in Europe, yet never takes the easy way out. Instead, it explores and resolutely preserves its hero's humanity.

The film's hurry to rush through its plethora of characters becomes a strength, because we don't have enough time to get bored by any one scene. The set pieces may be thin, but they show flickers of genuine warmth.

movie_title: Norman Lear: Just Another Version of You (2016)

It's alternately hysterical and heartbreaking, comedy by way of John Cassavetes, who gets an appropriate shout-out.

A small joy: a lighthearted, shaggy-yet-brief charmer with a pleasantly moralistic story that's like Sholem Aleichem by way of Seinfeld.
movie_title: The Tenth Man (El rey del Once) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A familiar sort of coming-of-age movie made more interesting by the uniqueness of its setting and its off-kilter Kiwi humor.
These two movies - one about family and one about freedom - never quite dovetail.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An honest, heartfelt paean to good old-fashioned love that's audacious in its wide-eyed passion, innocent love of fun and sheer showmanship.
Watch Some Kind Of Monster instead.
One of the liveliest Shakespeare adaps of the past 20 years ...
It's certainly a great performance from Scott, a seamless, pity-free portrayal.

There's an admirable refusal to canonise the prof, and we're left in no doubt that his life has not been plain sailing either for him or those he relies on ...
A highly enjoyable slice of in-one-eye, out-the-other nonsense. It may coast on the charisma of its leads at times, and it's hardly deep, but there's a Friday night to be had.
The CG sequences have dated horrendously.
It's impossible to hate a film where the cast is so game, but you may struggle to remember it the morning after.
You may not be sure what you've seen, but you've sure seen something.
Comes dangerously close to perpetuating rational man/hysterical woman stereotypes.

Even if you feel you know every scene backwards, there are still manifold pleasures here beyond nostalgia.

Offering a fascinating window into a world often distorted and oversimplified, this is informative, stimulating and moving stuff ...

movie_review_blurb: Nadia is nowhere to be seen and Stifler never surrenders the spotlight in what is the weakest link of the American Pie series.
